oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large brick school building, set in the Ducktown Basin of the southern Appalachian Mountains. It contains nuerous doors and windows. Etched in stone above the main doorway is "Kimsey Junior College." Above another entranceway, at the end of the building, is etched "Auditorium."
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Education Schoolhouse Photos, 1938-1942
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1940, the Ducktown School had thirteen classrooms, twelve teachers, and 486 students. M. L. Jones was the principal. The collegiate Gothic architecture is the only of its kind in the Copper Basin. The school, which was never used as a junior college, has been placed on the National Register of Historic Places.

The report issued by the Department of Education indicate that areas of deficiency, among others, included the school's scholastic record, community-mindedness, opportunities for athletic and cultural experiences, and science and shop.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This African American school had two classrooms, one teacher, and 56 students. The school was isolated, having no other schools nearby. Neither did it have a library, an encyclopedia, nor a dictionary. At least twenty-five cents a year was spent on each student but the structure itself was in very poor condition. Evidence of good housekeeping was observed. Evidently, the only source of heat was a fireplace at one end of the building.

Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of Old Neophagen, a white school in Benton County. The frame structure is set in the midst of trees, with two men appearing on the right.

During this period, the Tennessee State Board of Education was evaluating many one-room schools for possible consolidation. On the back of this image is recorded the following conclusion: "should be consolidated with Liberty." Old Neophagen was an eighth-grade school. Located on Highway 69A six miles north of Camden, it was first called Bells School. H. W. Presson is listed as the teacher for 1927-1928. This school was one of the oldest in Benton County and was eventually torn down.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of Old Matlock School, a white school in Benton County. A child carrying a case (possibly a lunch pail) and a young man carrying his hat are posing in front of the dilapidated log school.

During this time period, the Tennessee State Board of Education was evaluating many one-room schools for possible consolidation. Figures on the back of this image suggest that the Board was considering consolidating Old Matlock and Byrds Chapel Schools. The figures represent estimates for the building, grounds, and improvement costs foe the new school. Rachel Peebles is listed as the teacher for "Matlocks Chapel" for 1927-1928.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Hale School] Lillard School
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Rural schools; Educational facilities
Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Listed as the Lillard School in the State Board of Education Records, this photograph has been identified by Maryville natives as the William J. Hale School. The building is a large imposing brick structure situated on a hill. At the time the photograph was taken, there was snow on the roof. This building had a chimney in the back and nineteen windows can be seen across the front.

The William J. Hale School, located on McGhee Street in Maryville, was built in early 1930 with Rosenwald funds. The school opened in 1931 and Mrs. Octavia B. Hoard was the first principal. The Hale School replaced the T. B. Lillard School, built about 1910. The T. B. Lillard School was named for Thomas B. Lillard, an African American and progressive businessman from Maryville. The Lillard School was located at the rear of the A.M.E. Church on what is now Harper Avenue.

Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; Rosenwald, Julius, 1862-1932; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Side view of Bells Consolidated Rosenwald School in Crockett County. The prim-looking white schoolhouse has multiple windows and is set in a withered cornfield.

The Julius Rosenwald Fund was one of the private Northern philanthropic foundations that operated in Tennessee to aid the cause of black education. Crockett County received $5,200 in aid from the Fund for school construction by July 1, 1930. For Bells Consolidated School, Rosenwald contributed $900; public funds contributed $2,400; and black donors contributed $2,050.

Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front view of Old Bells School, a black school in Crockett County. At the time of the photograph, the school was abandoned.

In the first decades of the twentieth century, Tennessee made efforts to erect healthier and more modern schools, hire better trained teachers, provide for student transportation, and to more competently manage and supervise education practices. The state also embarked upon a program of consolidation and new construction so that schools like Old Bells Colored were abandoned. Bells Consolidated Rosenwald School replaced it.

It hoped to more competently manage and supervise schools, consolidate them, obtain better trained teachers, and provide for student transportation. Bucks Chapel School was a black school in Crockett County which did not receive Rosenwald Fund assistance.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Two entrances flanked by windows are visible in this front view of Mt. Zion Hebrew Colored School. Two white men wearing straw hats are standing in the front yard. In the distance are cattle and trees.

The Julius Rosenwald Fund was one of the private Northern philanthropic foundations that operated in Tennessee to aid the cause of black education. Fayette County received $13,000 from the Fund for school construction by July 1, 1930. For Mt. Zion Hebrew Colored Consolidated School, Rosenwald contributed $700; public funds contributed $1,500; and black donors contributed $1,300.

Famed World War I hero Alvin Cullum York (1887-1964) raised funds in order to provide impoverished Fentress County boys and girls the education that had been denied him. The result was a private agricultural school that operated from 1926 to 1937. In 1937, the General Assembly transferred operations to the State Board of Education.

After five years of fundraising, the community had the five hundred dollars needed for a government match to open a Rosenwald school. Matt Gardner was chairman of the colored school board.

War Creek School was in the first district of Hancock County. William B. Harrison served as superintendent of schools from 1928 to 1936. The school was listed as abandoned when photographed in 1931. This was probably a result of the consolidation of schools that took place in the first decades of the twentieth century as the state strove to improve its public school system.

Though undated, this facility fits into the pattern of improvements undertaken in the state's public education system in the first decades of the twentieth century. Offering housing for teachers working in Hardeman County schools would have been an incentive and would have had the potential to draw better trained teachers.

This school was in a rural area north of the Lee Highway. It was abandoned and consolidated with Liberty which was nearer to Lee Highway and probably more accessible. Many schools were abandoned due to the consolidation that took place in the first decades of the twentieth century. The state was striving to improve the public school system throughout Tennessee.

Hickman County High School was originally listed as Fairview Academy in Hickman County histories. As an academy, the building was opened in 1903. It is not known when it became the Hickman County High School. Although a historic building, it was not saved.

The Nelson Merry School was built Approximately 1890 through the efforts of the Reverend Peter Guinn, a black Baptist minister. The institution was named for the Reverend Nelson Merry, a pioneer Baptist who preached in Nashville. The school remained a Baptist academy until 1932 when control passed to Jefferson County. Construction of a new building was made possible through the Rosenwald Foundation (the photograph here is of the "old" structure). The school closed its doors in 1965.

The school was constructed in the late 1930s by the Works Progress Administration, consolidating several schools in Shady Valley, Johnson County. The WPA was the New Deal's largest agency and was created to carry out public works, including construction of roads, buildings and parks.

Opened in July 1929 with funding from the Rosenwald Foundation, this school for African American children of Hohenwald consisted of two classrooms, restrooms, and a kitchen. It served grades one through eight, replacing the old Hohenwald school for "colored" children. The institution closed in the mid-1960s.

This simple one-room wooden building was originally a church and was used as a school beginning in the early 1920s. Its first teacher was Ms. Ella Gray Allison, who continued teaching for over forty years. It was replaced by a "Rosenwald school" in 1929.

This beautiful home was built by W. W. Holt and was located on land bordering Church, Poplar and Magnolia Streets in Lynchburg. It was first used as a High School in the 1926-1927 academic year. It had four tall columns fronting the house, and there were two floors plus a basement. The house was chosen as the county high school in 1927 and served in that capacity until 1932. It was razed to make way for real estate development.

Education; Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front and side views of a small clapboard structure with a center chimney. The schoolhouse is set on stone pillars.

The town of Adams is located in the northwest section of Robertson County. The old school is emblematic of the educational opportunities available for African Americans in the first half of the twentieth century. Between 1910 and 1940, only 60% of white school-age children in Tennessee attended class. The rate was lower in the black communities.

The Mount Olive community was situated on the middle fork of Drakes Creek. One of the most prominent men from this area was James Durham who served in the War of 1812. The Durham Family is well-known in Sumner County.

Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee; Deaf - education
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large brick school building used for the Negro Department at the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It appears to be under construction.

The legislature passed a bill on April 4, 1881, establishing a school for the Negro deaf. The Negro school was closed at the beginning of the Christmas holidays in 1940 and an extensive improvement program began. Henry C. Edmunds, the principal, helped with the work. Modern electric and heating systems were installed; the floors and walls were replaced; and a cement-block extension was built onto the back of the main building.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: School buses; Buses; Vehicles; Transportation
Education - Tennessee; Education - History - Tennessee; School buildings - Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Passenger bus labeled "Tennessee School For The Deaf." It is parked in front of the Administration Building on the school's campus.

The Athletic Association of the Tennessee School for the Deaf revived a bus fund in the fall of 1938 and began seriously raising money to purchase a bus for the use of the athletic teams. The committee heading up this effort was composed of Chairman Conley Akin, Publicity Chairman J.M. Smith, Jr., and Treasurer Harley Bishop. Alumni, pupils, teachers, and friends contributed. The institution received its bus in the fall of 1940.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Log cabin perched on rocks and standing in a shady lot. The building has two windows, a chimney and a front door. Written on the back of the photograph is, "Used for the last time in the winter of 1926-27. Desks and interior similar to Mt. Pisgah School."

The Hill School House community was one of the oldest in the county. The log house was used for a school and a church. The church functioned until the 1920s. The old log schoolhouse was one of the last to be replaced in Pickett County.

The Macon County history books list the school only as Pisgah and it was probably built in the late 1800s. It stood on land once owned by Thomas Leath.
